comment_26:
I sing a lot of Sinatra. They tell me I do a pretty good job.

The melody of Summer Wind is beautiful. But I always felt that I was missing the true meaning of the words.

One day I met a man who was about the same age as sinatra, and he explained the song to me.

First------it has nothing to do with wind, as such.

It's about two young friends, lovers. They go to the East coast of the US for a two month summer vacation. After about a week, they are joined by a young fellow from Europe. Although they don't know him, a strong bond is quickly formed between the three. He just sort of 'blew in', like the summerwind.

"like painted kites those days and night went flyin' by..." etc.

Everything was great......for a while.

And then, "I lost you to the summerwind"  Yes, she develops a passion for the new guy who "came blowin' in from across the sea".

The first guy suffers through the autum and the winter, while the "summer wind" guy (the fickle friend) sighs "his lullabies" to his new girl friend, through nights that never end.

So in some ways it's a sad song and in some ways it's a happy song. It depends if you are the first guy or the second.

When I studied the song again, with this meaning, it all seemed to make sense.

frankisbac
